Okay, so I see 2 ways you're taking this argument, but neither makes much sense.
1) That renewables produce far less energy for the same investment, and must less Gwh less jobs are produced. [This still is not true](https://web.stanford.edu/group/emf-research/docs/occasional_papers/OP64.pdf). That research from Stanford indicates that 1 Gwh of solar PV produces between 0.846 and 1.205 jobs. Wind produces between 0.081 to 0.318. Natural gas produces 0.108 and coal 0.115.
2) That it produces much cheaper electricity which creates jobs elsewhere. On its face, that is [not significantly true]( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_electricity_by_source), but it depends who you go by. The EIA says wind and natural gas are roughly equal (natural gas slightly ahead), and solar is slightly more. Lazard says wind and solar are both slightly less than natural gas on the other hand. Either way, that doesn't really hold up.
Even if we use the more favorable numbers for natural gas that gives it a slight edge, it's pretty clear that the [economic damage from emissions and pollution](http://time.com/4082328/climate-change-economic-impact/) would cancel out any gains.

Its arguable, but impossible to say.
Right now, it would be impossible to run a decarbonized grid without nuclear in many locations. Its also a great option for those with very limited space (like Japan).
But it certainly isn't trending in the right direction, in America at least. The US added [1.1 GW of nuclear capacity in 2016](https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=25172). Along with 6.8 GW of wind, 8.0 of natural gas, and 9.5 of solar. That 1.1 GW was in the form of one reactor, the first and only brought online in 20 years.
Meanwhile, they've retired 5 GW of nuclear in the past [4 years alone](https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=30112).
The reason for this is pretty simple: [price](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_electricity_by_source?wprov=sfla1). Wind, solar, and natural gas are all significantly cheaper on average.
So right now things don't look good for nuclear. But nuclear has the huge advantage of being dispatchable over solar and wind. And in the future, that could bring nuclear to the forefront.
But thats an iffy 'could'. Unless things change, nuclear will be required for deep decarbonization of the grid. But deep decarbonization is still some time away. And it all depends what happens until that time. A lot of factors will play in: costs, load balancing, new technology, storage, among other things.
So it's not out of the question to say nuclear has no long-term future. Its highly debatable, but not surely false. It all depends on what happens in the coming years, so unless someone has a crystal ball, I don't think any of us can say what nuclears long-term future looks like. It may play a large role, a smaller one, or no role at all.
